channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Weekly Challenge 205
item.description: Use of CPAN can be handy when it comes to Perl. By the way Python is not far behind either.

item.title: Third Exclusive
item.description: Roger never misses the opportunity to use the power tool of the language. Well done and keep it up.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge #205
item.description: Simple for-loops is your friend this week. Robbie shared how? Thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: Weekly challenge 205
item.description: Task analysis of both tasks is well drafted, specially the second one. Just loved it. Thanks.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 205
item.description: Knows for this one-liner in Perl. He didn't disappoint us this week too. Well done.

item.title: nested loops in a rush!
item.description: Raku is playing the smart game and getting the job done without any trouble. Great job.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 205: Third Highest and Maximum (Bit-Wise) XOR
item.description: Compact one-liner (kind of) in both Perl and Raku. Nothing less was expected from Laurent. Thanks for your contributions.

item.title: PWC205 - Maximum XOR
item.description: Raku magical power can make any solutions look elegant. Great work, keep it up.

item.title: PWC205 - Third Highest
item.description: Straight forward solutions in Perl and Raku is shared week after week without any fuss. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 205
item.description: Beautifully crafted solutions in Perl as always. Thanks for sharing the nitty-gritty, hard to ignore.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 205
item.description: Classic Raku show of power. For anyone looking for Raku magic then this is the place.

item.title: Reset Content
item.description: Not just the title but the whole story plot is not to be missed. Highly Recommended.

item.title: Exclusive Third Or First
item.description: A very thorough blog post with lots of twist and turns. Great job and thanks for sharing.

item.title: The Highest Maximum
item.description: Yet another power packed solutions in Raku. Well done, keep it up.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 205
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Third Highest" and "Maximum XOR" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 206
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Shortest Time" and "Array Pairings". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: one-liner: remove the same line from many files
Ordering Your Tests
item.description: On one hand I think having the tests ordered can be a good idea, but on the other hand we will also want to make sure that the success of the tests does not depend on their order and that they can also be executed in parallel. So I am not really in favor of specifying the order of the test.

item.title: Template fragments with Mojolicious
item.description: It is about adding template fragment functionality to Mojolicious, for use with htmx.

item.title: Tantalizing TTD
item.description: I see TDD as an ideal that you can rarely attain. In green-field projects I rarely know how things should work so my test-writing lags behind the code-writing. However usually after 'some' development I start to feel the lack of tests and then my focus changes.

item.title: Assert Your Environment
item.description: When container image gets passed around, the information about the required env settings will certainly get lost. Here is something of a solution to that: How to ensure you have the environment variables and values you need?

item.title: First release of SPVM::File::Temp and SPVM::File::Find
item.description: SPVM (Static Perl Virtual Machine) is a perl-ish static typed programing language. SPVM provides fast calculation, fast array operations, easy C/C++ binding, and creating executable files.

item.title: Perl and Raku Merch from Freewear
item.description: A portion of the profit from each sale goes to TPRF

item.title: #605 - Trying to save a disappearing language
item.description:
Hi there!

In 1492 the Jews were expelled from Spain and 4 years later also from Portugal. Many of those Jews settled in the Ottoman Empire and kept talking and changing their language. This is what created the language we call 'Judeo-Espanyol' or in its modern name 'Ladino'. For 500 years these people kept speaking and improving their language which is now a mix of medieval Spanish, Portuguese, Catalan, Turkish, Greek, Italian, Hebrew, Arabic, and probably a few other languages. These Jews are usually referred to as the 'Sephardic' Jews because 'Sepharad' means Spain in Hebrew. It was originally written using old Hebrew letters called Rashi and Solitreo, but in the last 100 years or so it was switched to Latin letters.

Unfortunately due to various reasons (The modernization of Turkey by Atatürk, the Holocaust, emigration to USA, Israel and elsewhere) the majority of remaining Ladino speakers switched to the local language and today there are only a few ten thousands of native Ladino speakers, most of them above 60.

There are various grass-root projects to revitalize the language. One of them is called Kantoniko. It is a multi-lingual dictionary with sample sentences, audio, poster etc. There are also experiments to use the material for educational purposes for people who would like to learn Ladino. The project has some Open Source code written in Python and JavaScript. There is also a lot of data under various Creative-Commons licenses.

I know Python is not your cup of tea, but the whole project might be interesting to some of you and might take a look at it. I recorded a series of videos in English about the site and how to contribute to it.

Enjoy your week!
item.dc:subject: editorial
